title: 107_s2826
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Our Lady of Peace Act" and includes findings. The Congress finds that since 1994, over 689,000 individuals have been denied a gun due to failed background checks. States not computerizing criminal and mental illness records cause delays in background checks, affecting law-abiding gun owners. 25 States have automated less than 60% of felony criminal conviction records, while 33 States do not automate or share disqualifying mental health records. Additionally, in 13 States, domestic violence restraining orders are not automated or accessible by the national instant criminal background check system, and in 15 States, no domestic violence misdemeanor records are automated or accessible. SEC. 101. ENHANCEMENT OF FEDERAL AGENCIES PROVIDING INFORMATION TO NATIONAL INSTANT CRIMINAL BACKGROUND CHECK SYSTEM. The Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act is amended to require departments and agencies to electronically furnish records relating to individuals described in specific sections of the law to the Attorney General for inclusion in the system. If the basis for a record being made available no longer applies, the department or agency must provide a certification to that effect. The Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act is amended to require departments and agencies to provide records of individuals disqualified from acquiring firearms to the Attorney General for inclusion in the national instant criminal background check system. The Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service must cooperate in providing information on relevant records of disqualified persons, including illegal aliens and visitors on visas. SEC. 102. REQUIREMENTS TO OBTAIN WAIVER. Beginning 5 years after the enactment of this Act, a State can receive a waiver of the 10 percent matching requirement for National Criminal History Improvement Grants if it provides at least 95 percent of the required information. The waiver can last up to 5 years. The State must make available information on individuals disqualified from acquiring firearms under specific sections of title 922 for submission to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. The State must provide information on individuals disqualified from acquiring firearms under specific sections of title 922 for submission to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System. If the basis for making a record available no longer applies, the State must notify the Attorney General for removal from the system. The information provided can only be accessed for background check purposes. The State must certify to the Attorney General that 95 percent of required information on individuals disqualified from acquiring firearms has been provided. This includes those convicted of misdemeanor crimes of domestic violence. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for an offense to be considered a misdemeanor crime of domestic violence, which includes the use of physical force or a deadly weapon by a current or former spouse, parent, guardian, or someone in a similar relationship to the victim. The curr_chunk outlines the conditions for a person to be considered convicted of a misdemeanor crime of domestic violence, emphasizing the need for legal representation and a jury trial in the jurisdiction where the case was tried. The person must knowingly and intelligently waive the right to a jury trial or guilty plea to be considered convicted of a misdemeanor crime of domestic violence. A conviction may not count if it has been expunged, set aside, or pardoned, unless the pardon explicitly prohibits firearm possession. The State must provide the Attorney General with information on individuals adjudicated as mentally defective or committed to mental institutions for inclusion in the national instant criminal background check system. The State must provide the Attorney General with information on individuals adjudicated as mentally defective or committed to mental institutions for inclusion in the national instant criminal background check system. This includes defendants in criminal cases adjudicated as not guilty by reason of insanity, individuals who are a danger to others due to a mental disorder, those involuntarily committed to a mental institution, individuals lacking mental capacity to manage their affairs, and those found to be a danger to themselves due to a mental disorder. The subsection exempts individuals in mental institutions for observation or voluntarily committed, as well as information protected by doctor-patient privilege. The Attorney General will establish privacy regulations for information provided to the national instant criminal background check system. States have the authority to limit the use of records transmitted under this subsection. The Attorney General must report annually on States' progress in automating databases for firearm eligibility checks. SEC. 103. IMPLEMENTATION GRANTS TO STATES. The Attorney General shall provide grants to States for improving firearms eligibility determinations through information and identification technologies. Grant funds can be used for building databases related to background checks, assisting States with NICS checks, improving criminal record dispositions, and supplying mental health records to NICS. The Attorney General provides grants to States for enhancing firearms eligibility determinations through technology. States must supply mental health records and court-ordered domestic violence information to NICS. States must specify grant usage and may face penalties for misuse. $250,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004-2006. FBI cannot charge user fees for background checks under section 922(t) of title 18, US Code. TITLE II--FOCUSING FEDERAL ASSISTANCE ON THE IMPROVEMENT OF RELEVANT RECORDS

SEC. 201. CONTINUING EVALUATIONS. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Statistics is required to study and evaluate the national instant criminal background check system, including analyzing the operations of participating agencies. Reports on grants and best practices must be submitted to Congress annually. The Director may consider best practices for records related to individuals in certain sections of the United States Code for the national instant criminal background check system. TITLE III--GRANTS TO STATE COURTS FOR IMPROVEMENT IN AUTOMATION AND TRANSMITTAL OF DISPOSITION RECORDS. Grants authorized under Section 301. The Attorney General shall make grants to each State for improving the handling of criminal history dispositions and restraining orders. Funds must be used for assessing court capabilities for record automation in 2004 and implementing automation policies in subsequent years. The Attorney General authorizes appropriations of $125,000,000 annually for 2004-2006 to maintain arrest and conviction records in courts.
